title.narrative: F.a: Myanmar textile and mining industry working conditions

description.narrative: The top of the current economic development of Myanmar consist of textile industry, mining and construction + wood processing; these employ massive amount of people who grew up in dictatorship and know relatively little about their rights. The trade union movement of the country has returned from exile a few years ago, and organizing is progressing well, but because the work starts from the basics, the need for support is significant. The aim of the project is to support the industrial unions in Myanmar to grow their union density and educate workers on basic trade union issues, so that the unions can in the long run represent the interests of the workers through negotiations and advocacy work. The textile industry grows at the speed of one new factory per w eek, and Myanmar seems to be the last safe haven for international brands in their race to the bottom. For this reason, the project work links up with IndustriALL’s campaigning and advocacy around the global production chains in textile industry. In the mining sector, the biggest problems are in the dangerous nature of the work, as well as the low-income level despite the risks. In both sectors, workers are still far from a decent living wage. Project will be supported jointly by SASK and our Dutch sister organization. Additionally, FES of Germany, CFMEU of Australia and a Dutch NGO Fair Wear Foundation contribute to specified components of IndustriALL’s work in Myanmar. The beneficiaries are industry workers, especially those in textile and mining secto rs. IndustriALL staff coordinates and manages the project together with focal persons and leaderships of the Myanmar unions.
